replies.bodyText: We would not need the switch-case and the recovery, since this is already validated, before coming here.
replies.author: SupunS

replies.bodyText: In the null case, we can simply return the token.. similar to string-literal/int-literal
replies.author: SupunS

replies.bodyText: @SupunS No switch case means, ( ) is considered to be NIL_LITERAL kind and NULL is considered to be NULL_KEYWORD kind, and will have separate pareseNilLiteral( ), pareseNullKeyword( ) methods ?
replies.author: lochana-chathura

replies.bodyText: yes. For the null keyword, we can do the same way as, string literal
replies.author: SupunS

timeline.author: lochana-chathura

timeline.bodyText:
Don't need to handle () in basic literals.. It was added to deal with literals with a single token. So may be we could only handle null here.
For () lets use NIL_LITERAL and add it to the EXPRESSIONS alternatives array.
timeline.author: SupunS

replies.author: lochana-chathura

timeline.bodyText: Eventhough the endContext() is called here, startContext() is not called at the first switch-case of getNextRule() method for NIL_LITERAL.
timeline.author: SupunS

timeline.bodyText:
A context is not started for null keyword.. So ending the context here is not correct.
We might not need any context for null keyword at all. It is very similar to string literal, int literal etc. A context is needed when a token can occur in different contexts/places  and if we can't determine whats next rule should be.. Then we make use of the parent context.
timeline.author: SupunS
